boat.name: Plum of Mylor
boat.full_description:
The name 'Plum' was given by the original owners and, as it is thought to be unlucky to re-name a boat, has never changed. Other than the obvious fruit connection, the word Plum means 'good'!

Plum is a gaff-cutter, Heard 23, built by Martin Heard at the Gaffers and Luggers boatyard at Mylor in Cornwall in 1990. The design is based on the Falmouth Working Boat, which evolved for fishing and shellfish dredging in the mid 1800s. There is a bye-law in the Fal Estuary, in Cornwall, which forbids oysters to be fished for by boats under mechanical power and even today Falmouth Working Boats from the Gaffers and Luggers boatyard can be seen dredging for shellfish under sail. This is the world’s last Oyster dredging fleet to work under sail alone and at it’s peak in 1924/25, there were 50 boats working the Fal fishery.

Plum has a glass-reinforced-plastic (GRP) hull with a wood deck and superstructure and wood (Columbian pine) spars.
boat.construction_details: GRP hull, wood deck and superstructure
boat.short_description: Plum of Mylor is a Heard 23. Often sailed single handed and a regular participant at the East Coast OGA events.
